cards.title: Athletics / Alberto Salazar denies his relationship with Mo Farah has broken down
cards.rawTitle: Alberto Salazar denies his relationship with Mo Farah has broken down

item.title: Alberto Salazar denies his relationship with Mo Farah has broken down
item.trailText: Alberto Salazar has rubbished speculation of a relationship breakdown between himself and Mo Farah following doping allegations made against the coach
item.standFirst:
• ‘Mo is on a different training cycle, as he always is,’ says Salazar
• Farah has returned from the US and is training in France
item.body:
Mo Farah’s coach has rubbished speculation of a relationship breakdown between himself and the double Olympic champion. Alberto Salazar, along with Farah’s training partner Galen Rupp, is under the microscope over doping allegations made by the BBC’s Panorama programme.

Both men have denied the allegations, while Farah has not been accused of doing anything wrong.

Farah, who himself has been placed under scrutiny after it was revealed by the Daily Mail he missed two drugs tests in the buildup to London 2012, travelled to his Portland training base to seek answers from Salazar last week.

Related: Mo Farah enlists PR experts to tackle missed drug tests controversy

On Wednesday he had flown back from the US and was training in France, which led to rumours that Farah was trying to distance himself from his coach.

However, speaking to the Oregonian newspaper, Salazar insisted Farah was still under his tutelage as he prepares to return to the track at the Monaco Diamond League meeting next month.

“Mo is on a different training cycle, as he always is at this time of year,” he said. “So I send him to Europe to get accustomed to the time zone. This is how we’ve always done it.

“This winter Barry [Fudge, a UK Athletics official who reports Farah’s progress to Salazar] administered my workouts to Mo in Ethiopia for six weeks, and Mo broke the world two-mile record.”

Farah, meanwhile, has been backed by his British team-mate and fellow distance runner Hannah England, who has called the stories surrounding the 32-year-old a “witch-hunt”.

England, who won silver at the 2011 world championships in Daegu, said in the Independent: “I feel it’s turning into a witch-hunt against Mo.

Related: Mo Farah being left on back straight in race to protect reputation

“There’s been a lot of very serious allegations made in recent days and that’s very newsworthy but it’s like people are finding some way to bring down Mo with it.

“I think it’s irresponsible that this has become such a big story without a proper explanation. It’s not what people are making it seem like.

“There’s just a lot of speculation going around. People are ruining Mo’s reputation and ruining the sport.”

Farah was revealed to have missed tests in 2010 and 2011, the second of which came after he failed to hear his doorbell. Under the ’three strikes’ system, a third missed appointment would have counted as a doping offence carrying a maximum four-year ban.

UK Anti-Doping’s (UKAD) chief executive, Nicole Sapstead, has admitted it is “not common” for an athlete to have two missed tests.

Last year there were 266 British athletes on the testing register, each of whom would have a minimum of three tests a year, and there were a total of 37 missed tests.

Between 2010 and 2014 there were 224 missed tests with the highest number in 2011 – the year before the London Olympics – with 66 missed tests but 99 more athletes in the testing pool compared to last year.

Video evidence submitted to UKAD by Farah’s agent, Ricky Simms, aiming to show the runner had not heard the doorbell may also have helped avert any possible charge for deliberately trying to evade testers.

Related: Missed drug tests happen but three strikes and out feels about right | Owen Gibson

Under the ’whereabouts’ system, athletes have to register where they will be for a specific hour every day so that testers can be sure of their location. If they are not where they say they will be three times in the space of a year then it is judged as a doping offence.

Sapstead would not discuss individual cases or reveal how many athletes were on two strikes but said: “It is not common for athletes to have two missed tests.”

UKAD’s legal director, Graham Arthur, said any evidence of a deliberate attempt to avoid testers would lead to an immediate doping charge.

Arthur said: “If someone has deliberately not opened their door and deliberately hidden from the testers then we would take action against them for evasion, which carries up to a four-year ban.

“If they have put themselves in a place where they are not able to hear the doping control people arrive or ring the doorbell and we are satisfied they are just being negligent and not wilful, then it counts as a missed test.”

cards.title: Rugby league / State of Origin looks to expand venues following Melbourne record
cards.rawTitle: State of Origin looks to expand venues following Melbourne record

item.title: State of Origin looks to expand venues following Melbourne record
item.trailText: State of Origin would go “gangbusters” in New Zealand, according to the promoters of the NRL Nines, as the game’s powerbrokers move to further expand the reach of the interstate series
item.standFirst: • Record crowd of 91,513 inspires organisers to look towards NZ, Perth
item.body:
State of Origin would go “gangbusters” in New Zealand, according to the promoters of the NRL Nines, as the game’s powerbrokers move to further expand the reach of the interstate series.

Buoyed by the phenomenal success of Origin II in Melbourne, the NRL have signalled their intention to take the game’s showpiece to Perth and internationally to New Zealand.

A record crowd of 91,513 jammed into the MCG to witness NSW’s 26-18 win in game two to further impress Origin’s standing as rugby league’s showpiece event.

Dates for the 2016 and 2017 series have already been locked in with the MCG down to host another game in 2018.

That means Auckland’s Eden Park will have to wait until at least 2019 to host Origin.

But Dave Higgins, Director of Duco Events, who have played a leading hand in creating the incredible success of the NRL Auckland Nines, said Origin would be embraced in New Zealand.

“Origin has all the ingredients to be a success in New Zealand,” Higgins told AAP.

“It would be massive over here and I have no doubt it would sell out a 50,000-seat Eden Park.

“I am sure 10s of thousands of fans would come across from Australia and from other parts of New Zealand it would definitely be a case of demand outstripping supply.”

“It would go gangbusters over here.”

Higgins said his company had yet to be sounded out by the NRL for such a project, but they were ideally placed to help get it going given their relationship with the NRL. The Nines has sold out for its first two years.

“I believe it is a matter of when, not if, State of Origin comes to New Zealand,” Higgins said.

Wednesday’s MCG crowd was a record for an Origin match at the venue and enjoyed record TV ratings, peaking at 4.540 million people, to become the highest rating show in 2015 so far.

Origin II was the highest rating interstate game ever in Melbourne.

displayImages.credit: Scott Barbour/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Greg Inglis

headerImage.caption: Greg Inglis runs with the ball during Game II of the State of Origin series between the New South Wales Blues and the Queensland Maroons. Photograph: Scott Barbour/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Greg Inglis runs with the ball during Game II of the State of Origin series between the New South Wales Blues and the Queensland Maroons.

snap.title: State of Origin looks to expand venues following Melbourne record

cards.title: Snooker / Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
cards.rawTitle: Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match

item.title: Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
item.trailText: Ronnie O’Sullivan has claimed he was offered money to throw a snooker match but turned it down as the risk was not worth taking
item.standFirst:
• Five-times world champion says the risk is not worth taking
• Stephen Lee’s 12-year ban has scared a lot of players, he adds
item.body:
Ronnie O’Sullivan, the five-times world snooker champion, has said he was offered money to throw a match but declined.

Speaking on The Clare Balding Show, which will air on BT Sport and BBC Two this week, O’Sullivan claimed other players did accept bribes in the past but said he believed the problem had been eradicated after Stephen Lee was banned for match-fixing.

O’Sullivan said: “I was offered money once to throw a game but I couldn’t do it. It’s your sport, you love your sport. They smell it anyway. The risk is just not worth taking and I couldn’t live with myself if I got involved in that.”

In 2012 Lee was suspended on match-fixing charges and the former world No5 was subsequently handed a 12-year ban.

Related: Stephen Lee banned from snooker for 12 years for seven match-fixing charges

“I don’t think it’ll go on in snooker any more because they really made an example of Stephen Lee,” O’Sullivan added. “They banned him for 12 years and I think a lot of the guys that were at it, they’re thinking they wouldn’t be able to play snooker ever again.

“So I think it’s been stamped out of snooker now and if anyone was to do it, they know what the consequences are.”

Three weeks ago, the Irish amateur John Sutton was banned for six years after the sport’s world governing body found him guilty of match-fixing and misusing inside information.

The World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association said Sutton’s offences related to suspicious betting on his match against Scotland’s Jamie Burnett in the qualifying stages of the International Championship.

cards.title: US sports / Tiger Woods' remarkable US Open decline is marked by its inevitability
cards.rawTitle: Tiger Woods' remarkable US Open decline is marked by its inevitability

item.title: Tiger Woods' remarkable US Open decline is marked by its inevitability
item.trailText: Tiger Woods’ day one capitulation is a fresh chapter of frustration for the fourteen-time major winner, but an entirely predicable one
item.standFirst: Tiger Woods’ day one capitulation is a fresh chapter of frustration for the fourteen-time major winner, but an entirely predicable one
item.body:
For Tiger Woods, the saddest aspect of an opening round of 80 at the US Open is the lack of eyebrows that will be raised on account of it.

The chapters of ignominy keep on flowing for a player who had carded just one professional round of 80 or more from a total of 1,107 between 1996 and 2014. This year, he has trebled that number.

Fifteen years to the day since Woods won the US Open by 15 shots, he topped a three-wood from the middle of the 18th fairway at Chambers Bay into the deepest bunker on the course. Already nine over par, his hopes of breaking 80 suddenly vanished. He has rarely looked so dejected, so beaten, so incapable of the rousing return for which many golfing fans long.

Related: Henrik Stenson and Dustin Johnson rise above mishaps to lead US Open

This has become painful viewing, which leaves onlookers to wonder just how Woods truly feels about his sharp demise. For all he has been adamant that more competitive play is the key to improved performance, the 14-time major winner is suffering embarrassment after embarrassment in front of the watching world. Cole Hammer, a 15-year-old amateur, outscored Woods by three here.

After what seems an inevitable missed cut on the outskirts of Seattle, it would be no real surprise if Woods opts to take another break from tournament play. Despite his positive comment to the contrary, there is no evidence whatsoever that Woods can threaten, let alone dominate, leaderboards. Woods has more rounds in the 80s during this season than the 60s. Some form of reassessment is required.

Prior to Thursday, his highest-scoring single US Open round was 77; that was as an amateur in 1996. Chambers Bay witnessed the fourth highest round of Woods’s professional career. To his credit, and in a departure from what plenty others would do in the same lamentable scenario, a sanguine Woods faced the media thereafter. He had just produced a back nine of 41.

“I’m not very happy, that’s for sure,” said the 39-year-old. “It was a tough day. I got off to a bad start and then just couldn’t quite get it turned around.

“It’s one of those things, just got to work through it. I’m trying as hard as I can to do it, and for some reason I just can’t get the consistency that I’d like to have out there.

“I fought, I fought hard. And that was my number. I couldn’t grind out any harder than that. So that’s just the way I played and unfortunately it was a high number today.”

Woods admitted this is as challenging a period as he has ever encountered. His solution? “Keep working. Keep grinding and keep working.”

The 13th hole at Chambers Bay has the widest fairway in US Open history; Woods missed it. He triple bogeyed the 14th. Earlier, at the 8th, his club flew into the air from his hands as he played from wild rough. The 16th witnessed his solitary birdie.

There was also a smile. If Woods’s score wasn’t a shock, the 81 of Rickie Fowler, one of his playing partners, certainly was. “The bright side is, at least I kicked Rickie’s butt today,” Woods said. That sense of humour has never been more necessary.

Fowler has been the model of recent major championship consistency and was many people’s tip to claim this event. Barring something astonishing, he won’t survive for the weekend. Only one player, a club professional named Rich Berberian, scored worse on day one than Fowler.

Henrik Stenson and Dustin Johnson shared the lead at five under par 65. Patrick Reed lies a shot adrift.

displayImages.credit: Harry How/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: A frustrating day at the office for Tiger Woods

headerImage.caption: Tiger Woods reacts to a shot from the rough on the eighth hole during the first round of the 115th U.S. Open Championship at Chambers Bay. Photograph: Harry How/Getty Images
headerImage.altText: A frustrating day at the office for Tiger Woods
headerImage.cleanCaption: Tiger Woods reacts to a shot from the rough on the eighth hole during the first round of the 115th U.S. Open Championship at Chambers Bay.

snap.title: Tiger Woods' remarkable US Open decline is marked by its inevitability | Ewan Murray

image.credit: Harry How/Getty Images
image.altText: A frustrating day at the office for Tiger Woods

cards.title: Australia sport / Brumbies must exorcise the ghost of Jake White to beat Stormers
cards.rawTitle: Brumbies must exorcise the ghost of Jake White to beat Stormers

item.title: Brumbies must exorcise the ghost of Jake White to beat Stormers
item.trailText: If the Brumbies are to recreate their Super Rugby semi-final glory of 2013 they need to abandon the predictable kicking game instilled under their former coach
item.standFirst: If the Brumbies are to recreate their Super Rugby semi-final glory of 2013 they need to abandon the predictable kicking game instilled under their former coach
item.body:
Winning this year’s Super Rugby title might be a plane trip too far for the Brumbies, but they are more than capable of springing an upset against the Stormers in the second qualifying final in Capetown early on Sunday morning.

There’s plenty of statistical sway going for the Stormers at home, including an unbeaten five home game stretch, seven from eight wins when hosting Australian sides, and three wins from four of the last four games against the Brumbies.

Daunting numbers indeed.

For all that, the Brumbies have heard South African teams talk up their play-offs home record before - two years ago, in fact, when they had to travel to Pretoria to play the Bulls in the 2013 semi-final. The Bulls had a formidable record then, winning 91.6% of home games against Australian and New Zealand sides going back five years. The Brumbies rolled them 26-23. And Stephen Larkham’s side should have every confidence of repeating the road dog trick at Newlands.

But there is a significant proviso: the Brumbies will have to use their potent backline weapons far more effectively, and more often.

In fact, one could argue the Brumbies have struggled this season to find the right balance between kicking, forward carries and backline attacking play. A lot of this is down to former coach Jake White’s legacy of hardwiring players to punt anything and everything inside their own half.

The Brumbies are a well-drilled enough side that they can put together winning seasons with this approach. But be that as it may, finals are a sudden death one-off event, and the Brumbies’ predictable approach has yet to deliver them a title, even though they’ve been rated strong contenders since their 2013 revival.

The tragedy for Brumbies supporters is that their team has a backline that could be every bit as good as the Hurricanes’ and Waratahs’– but only if they disavow Jake-ball once and for all.

It’s time to let the likes of Joe Tomane, Tevita Kuridrani, Henry Speight and Jessie Mogg have a crack from wherever their instincts tell them to. In fact, it’s a wonder the Brumbies don’t flip their game upside down – that is, run from inside their own half, and put up contestable kicks in the opposition half so as to exploit opportunities for what is the best line-out driving maul in the competition.

The Brumbies came close to knocking off the Stormers at Newlands barely a month ago, going down 25-24 in a stop-start snorefest. Hopefully, coach Larkham would have heeded the lesson dished out by the Crusaders last week – you actually have to play rugby to win against the good sides. (As an aside, the Crusaders must be ruing their early season wobbles as in the form they were in last week, only a brave soul would bet against them snaring an eighth title.)

The Brumbies have an excellent chance of winning this weekend if they run the ball. The Stormers don’t like being run around the park. Of their five losses this season, four have come against teams who shift the ball – the Cheetahs, Hurricanes, Highlanders, and Chiefs. There’s a lesson there, which if heeded could bode well for the travelling Brumbies. And, if all else fails, the Brumbies still have that man David Pocock who remains the bogeyman of all South African sides since the controversial 2011 Rugby World Cup Australia vs South Africa quarter-final. Pocock could simply spook the Stormers in the end just like he did to the Boks that day.

Will the Highlanders magic run continue?

Everyone loves the Highlanders, even the bagmen who have them short favourites against the 2012-13 champions the Chiefs in the first qualifying final on Saturday afternoon. It’s hard to disagree. The Highlanders have been magnificent this season and an absolute joy to watch, especially their world class backline starring All Black trio Ben and Aaron Smith, and Malakai Fekitoa. Then there are the Fijian flyers Patrick Osbourne and Waisake Naholo on the wings, and the soon-to-be All Black Lima Sopoaga pulling the strings at fly-half. It would appear many have the Highlanders pegged as good things given then have already beaten the Chiefs this season, 36-9 in round 16. However, that score is deceptive as Chiefs’ key big men Brodie Retallick and Matt Symons were out. That second-row combination is back, as are Sonny Bill Williams and Tim Nanai-Williams in the midfield. The Dunedin clash should go down to the wire. One suspects as good as the Highlanders’ backline is, their no-name forwards might struggle against a Chiefs pack with tackling machines Sam Cane, Liam Messam and Retallick coming into All Black form.


Super Rugby Qualifying Finals

Saturday

Highlanders v Chiefs – 5.35pm (AEST)

Sunday

Stormers v Brumbies – 1.05am

displayImages.credit: Lukas Coch/AAP
displayImages.altText: David Pocock

headerImage.caption: The fitness and form of David Pocock could prove vital to the Brumbies, if they are to upset the Stormers at home. Photograph: Lukas Coch/AAP
headerImage.cleanCaption: The fitness and form of David Pocock could prove vital to the Brumbies, if they are to upset the Stormers at home.

snap.title: Brumbies must exorcise the ghost of Jake White to beat Stormers

cards.title: Olympic Games 2016 / GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa
cards.rawTitle: GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa

item.title: GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa
item.trailText: Alex Danson hailed a ‘really professional performance’ by Great Britain after their 2-0 win over South Africa
item.standFirst:
• Reading striker Alex Danson gives Great Britain 12th-minute lead
• Ireland suffer 4-3 World League shootout defeat by China
item.body:
Great Britain’s women are one win away from Olympic qualification after a fifth successive victory at the World League tournament in Valencia.

Two goals in the opening 14 minutes were enough to beat South Africa 2-0. The victory took them into the World League final in Argentina in December but, more importantly, a top-three finish in this tournament will guarantee a spot at the Rio 2016 Games.

The Reading striker Alex Danson scored her third goal of the competition with a clever spin and shot in the 12th minute and then her club-mate Kate Richardson-Walsh’s deflected penalty corner flew in off the underside of the crossbar.

“We are absolutely delighted. It was a really professional performance by the team,” Danson said. “I think the work we do back home puts us in a good position here; fitness is a key thing and we still have a lot left in the legs.”

Great Britain will face the winners of Germany against Spain in Saturday’s semi-final.

Ireland’s hopes of securing automatic Olympic qualification for the first time were cruelly dashed in a 4-3 shootout defeat by China.

Having conceded an early goal, Ireland deservedly equalised through Chloe Watkins with 18 minutes to go and they were denied a winner when Megan Frazer’s goal was disallowed after an umpire’s video referral.

Ayeisha McFerran was put in goal for the shootout and made two saves but, when Nicola Evans missed the chance to win on the last of the five regulation attempts they lost out in the second round of sudden death.

Ireland’s diminishing hopes of reaching Brazil next year rest with them finishing fifth and hoping results at other qualifying competitions later this year go their way.

displayImages.caption: A big wave of water pours over the top of the watch team of Xabi Fernandez, Antonio Cuervas - Mons ‘eti’ and Willy Altadill onboard MAPFRE Photograph: Francisco Vignale/MAPFRE/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
displayImages.credit: Francisco Vignale/MAPFRE/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
displayImages.altText: A big wave of water pours over the top of the watch team of Xabi Fernandez, Antonio Cuervas - Mons 'eti' and Willy Altadill onboard MAPFRE
displayImages.cleanCaption: A big wave of water pours over the top of the watch team of Xabi Fernandez, Antonio Cuervas - Mons ‘eti’ and Willy Altadill onboard MAPFRE
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Francisco Vignale/MAPFRE/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image

displayImages.caption: Team SCA are the first team into Lorient, France and win the stage in a time of 3 days, 13 hours, 11 minutes and 11 seconds Photograph: Rick Tomlinson/Team SCA/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
displayImages.credit: Rick Tomlinson/Team SCA/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Team SCA are the first team into Lorient, France and win the stage
displayImages.cleanCaption: Team SCA are the first team into Lorient, France and win the stage in a time of 3 days, 13 hours, 11 minutes and 11 seconds
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Rick Tomlinson/Team SCA/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: One hour, 26 minutes and 35 seconds later the Dongfeng Race Team was the final yacht to arrive in Lorient to finish in seventh place Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
displayImages.credit: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: One hour, 26 minutes and 35 seconds later the Dongfeng Race Team was the final yacht to arrive in Lorient to finish in seventh place
displayImages.cleanCaption: One hour, 26 minutes and 35 seconds later the Dongfeng Race Team was the final yacht to arrive in Lorient to finish in seventh place
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Team SCA celebrate their victory during the prize giving ceremony in Lorient Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
displayImages.credit: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Team SCA celebrate their victory during the prize giving ceremony in Lorient
displayImages.cleanCaption: Team SCA celebrate their victory during the prize giving ceremony in Lorient
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

snap.title: Volvo Ocean Race: stage eight – in pictures
